title: 106_hr807
content: The Act is titled the "Federal Reserve Board Retirement Portability Act" and it focuses on the portability of service credit. The "Federal Reserve Board Retirement Portability Act" amends Section 8411(b) of title 5, United States Code to include a period of service that was creditable under the Bank Plan, if the employee waives credit for such service. The "Federal Reserve Board Retirement Portability Act" allows employees to waive credit for service under the Bank Plan by making a payment to the Fund equal to the deducted amount from pay under section 8422(a). The term "Bank Plan" refers to the benefit structure for employees appointed by the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System after January 1, 1984. The Federal Reserve System appointed employees after January 1, 1984, can participate in the Retirement Plan. Employees can waive credit for service under the Bank Plan by making a payment to the Fund. Employees eligible for the Retirement Plan must have completed at least 5 years of civilian service creditable under specific acts, including the Foreign Service Act of 1980 and the Federal Reserve Act. Employees eligible for the Retirement Plan must have completed at least 5 years of civilian service creditable under specific acts, including the Foreign Service Act of 1980 and the Federal Reserve Act, or other relevant service creditable under subchapter III of chapter 83 of this title. The Retirement Plan for Federal Reserve System employees, established under the Federal Reserve Act, exempts individuals from certain requirements related to deposits or service structure. This exception does not apply to individuals who do not meet specific criteria outlined in the United States Code. Individuals exempt from certain requirements under the Retirement Plan for Federal Reserve System employees are those who fall under specific benefit structures outlined in the Foreign Service Act of 1980 or the Federal Reserve Act. The Retirement Plan for Federal Reserve System employees exempts certain individuals who meet specific benefit structures outlined in the Foreign Service Act of 1980 or the Federal Reserve Act, including former employees with at least 5 years of civilian service creditable under the benefit structure for employees appointed before January 1, 1984. Employees appointed after January 1, 1984, under the benefit structure of the Retirement Plan for Employees of the Federal Reserve System, are entitled to benefits under chapter 84 of title 5, United States Code. This provision is considered for the Federal Employees' Retirement System Act of 1986. Employees appointed after January 1, 1984, under the Retirement Plan for Employees of the Federal Reserve System are entitled to benefits under chapter 84 of title 5, United States Code. The Federal Employees' Retirement System Act of 1986 allows individuals who separate from service under this chapter to receive benefits. The effective date of this Act and its amendments is the date of enactment. The amendments in subsection (b) do not apply to former employees of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System who were under subchapter III of chapter 83 or chapter 84 of title 5, United States Code before the enactment of this Act. Certain transfers will be considered as a separation from service for the Thrift Savings Plan. Certain transfers to be treated as a separation from Government employment for the Thrift Savings Plan under Chapter 84 of Title 5, United States Code. Certain transfers to be treated as a separation from Government employment for the Thrift Savings Plan under Chapter 84 of Title 5, United States Code. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections for chapter 84 of title 5, United States Code. Section 4 of the document includes clarifying amendments related to certain transfers being treated as separations from Government employment for the Thrift Savings Plan under Chapter 84 of Title 5, United States Code. The amendments also address the effective date of these changes and empower the Executive Director to prescribe necessary regulations. SEC. 4 of the document includes clarifying amendments to section 3304 of title 5, United States Code. The amendments specify that preference eligible or veteran individuals shall acquire competitive status and receive a career or career-conditional appointment if selected. Effective date of these changes is retroactive to October 31, 1998.
